Authors: Pingting Chen, Longqing Chen, Jun Wen
Title:
The first phylogenetic analysis of Tetrastigma (Miq.)
Planch., the host of Rafflesiaceae
Keywords:
Phylogeny; Tetrastigma; Vitaceae; plastid DNA; Rafflesia;
Rafflesiaceae
Abstract:
Tetrastigma (Vitaceae), comprising about 95 species widely
distributed throughout subtropical and tropical Asia extending to
Australia. Meanwhile it is best known for the host plants of
Rafflesiaceae (including Rafflesia, with the largest flower in the
world. The phylogeny of Tetrastigma, however, remains poorly known. Four
plastid markers (trnL-trnF intergenic spacer, rps16 intron, atpB-rbcL
intergenic spacer, and psbA-trnH intergenic spacer) were employed to
infer the first phylogeny of Tetrastigma. Our sampling included eleven
reported host species of Rafflesiaceae, and these eleven species were
scattered in seven major clades throughout the Tetrastigma tree,
suggesting multiple origins of the parasite-host relationship. Analysis
of 114 accessions representing 53 species and four varieties throughout
the distributional range of the genus provided robust support for the
monophyly of Tetrastigma, yet Tetrastigma is supported to be nested
within Cayratia. Tetrastigma subgenus Palmicirrata from the
Sino-Himalayan region is nested within the large and widely distributed
subgenus Tetrastigma. Two major clades (clades A and F) in our phylogeny
correspond to section Tetrastigma and section Carinata of subgenus
Tetrastigma, respectively.
